SHOP ASSISTANTS EMPLOYMENT BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Labour and Welfare (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, I have His Excellency's consent to the Second Reading of this Bill.

    Sir, in moving the Second Reading of the Clerks Employment Bill yesterday, I had already covered most of the ground in respect of this Bill. I cannot think that hon. Members need to be convinced of the need for legislation to protect shop assistants. As a class of worker, they have never been very vocal in demanding this or that. Nevertheless, Sir, since assuming office as Minister for Labour, I have received a steady stream of letters from shop assistants outlining their grievances and asking that some sort of protective legislation be devised to assist them. These grievances, Sir, can be summarised very simply: that their contracts of service are so vague that they never know exactly what rights they have under them; that their employers make all sorts of deductions from their

Column: 302

salaries, especially when they wish to resign and they have asked that their wages be settled in full; that their wages are seldom paid regularly; that their hours of work are too long; and that holidays or sick leave are grudgingly given. And they have asked particularly, Sir, that they should be given the right to have their complaints settled in the Labour Court. All these grievances will be removed when the Bill before this House becomes law.

    The opportunity has also been taken to include earlier legislation for shop assistants, namely, the Weekly Holidays Ordinance and the Seats for Shop Assistants Ordinance.

    Sir, it is Government's intention to commit this Bill to a Select Committee and any comments that hon. Members may have on this Bill will, of course, be fully considered by the Select Committee when appointed. Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure this Charter of Rights for shop assistants will be hailed with satisfaction by shop assistants all over Singapore. It is common knowledge, Sir, that shop assistants are being made to work at present from anything up to 9 to 12 hours a day; in some cases up to 13 hours a day. Consequently they get very little time off for healthy recreation or relaxation. This Bill, Sir, seeks to limit the working hours of shop assistants to 8 or, in certain cases, to 9 hours a day at contracted wages, and the maximum fixed per week is 44 hours in normal cases.

    Sir, this Bill also seeks to uplift the status of shop assistants in Singapore from that of mere machines, used for profit earning for employers, to that of human beings.

    This Bill, Sir, as also the Clerks Employment Bill which had its Second Reading yesterday, goes to prove that the Labour Front Coalition Government is continuously seeking to better the lot of the working class, and no matter what amount of propaganda is made by certain Members of the Opposition who seek

Column: 303

to set themselves up as champions of the working class, I am sure this fact will not go into hiding.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have only two points I wish to make. The first refers to clause 37 (1) on the subject of an additional half-day holiday for shop assistants, theatre and restaurant employees. There is often a considerable difference between the hours of working of shop assistants and restaurant employees, the latter, in some cases, working either wholly or mainly in the evenings. In this sub-clause, therefore, in line 3 on page 11 of the Bill the words,

    "every shop assistant employed therein shall be allowed in each week an additional holiday of one half-day commencing at such hour in the afternoon as may be fixed by the Minister",

may mean, unless the words "in the afternoon" are omitted, that some restaurant employees will get another full day's holiday per week instead of a half holiday, which I do not think is the intention of this Bill. This is a matter which will have to be looked into further in Select Committee.

    Secondly, I must draw the attention of the Minister once again to clauses 48 to 50 regarding the very wide powers given to inspectors. Yesterday I questioned, in respect of similar clauses in the Clerks Employment Bill, the need in clause 48 to "enter without previous notice at any hour of the day or night any place where he has reason to believe any shop assistant is employed". And I also queried the omission in clause 50 (a) of a proviso to be found in section 9 (2) of the present Weekly Holidays Ordinance that "no person shall be compellable to answer any question if the answer may tend directly or indirectly to incriminate". Sir, I asked the Hon. the Chief Minister to justify the very wide powers being given to inspectors and yesterday he omitted to give me a reply. I hope that he will do so today.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock rose -

    Mr Speaker: In reply?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Yes, Sir. Mr Speaker, Sir, may I point out to the Member for Tanglin that clauses 48 to

Column: 304

50 were taken from the Labour Ordinance which was approved in the previous session of the Legislative Assembly? The operation of these two sections in the Labour Ordinance has been done in a very fair and just manner and no complaints have been received by the Government in regard to any unjust operation. But in view of the representations made by the hon. Member, the points which he has raised will, of course, be duly considered by Government in Select Committee.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.

CONTROL OF IMPORTS AND EXPORTS ORDINANCE
(Continuation in force)


    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move,

    That this Assembly, in accordance with subsection (2) of section 1 of the Control of Imports and Exports Ordinance (Chapter 214), resolves that the aforesaid Ordinance shall continue in force for a further period of one year commencing on the 8th day of December, 1956.

    Sir, on five previous occasions this Ordinance has come up before the Legislature of this colony for its continuance and has been approved each time for a period of one year. My motion now seeks to extend the continuance of this Ordinance for a further period of one year as from the 8th of December, 1956.

    This Ordinance gives the Minister for Commerce and Industry powers to make orders prohibiting the import and export of goods. However, let me assure Members that, in keeping with our free trade policy, these powers are used very sparingly, and except for a comparatively narrow field, most imports are placed on the open general licence and exports are freely licensed. The powers of control, however, come in useful in regulating imports for balance of payment reasons, especially from hard-currency areas, but here again all essential and many semi-essential goods are licensed freely.

    These powers also provide a useful check for purposes of disease control in connection with the import of plants, animals and meats.

     Hon. Members will recall that these powers were used a few months ago to prohibit the importation of pin-tables and similar amusement machines.

    In the export field the powers under this Ordinance are used to keep a check on the export of strategic materials and essential items in short supply in Singapore. At present, controls on exports are very few in number. It is, however, necessary for the Minister to have such powers of control, and the Trade Advisory Council agrees with this view. Sir, I beg to move.

Column: 306



    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): I second it.

    Question proposed.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, on receiving the assurance of the Minister that these powers will be used sparingly and with the advice of the Trade Advisory Council, I am not opposing the motion before the House.

    This morning I read a rather alarming report about rubber exports to China. A trade mission has left for China from Singapore and the Federation, and has concluded deals in rubber for export to China. If the report in the Press is correct - that Government requires a guarantee from the exporter that this rubber will not be used for war purposes - how is the exporter to know how that commodity will be used in China? It is impossible for an exporter here to give any guarantee or surety. On the other hand, Sir, all these years rubber has been exported through the United Kingdom to Russia. Then why is this guarantee required from exporters that the rubber exported to China will not be used for war purposes? As I have said, it is impossible for exporters to know to what uses the rubber will be put. I hope the Government will not try and put obstacles in the export and import trade.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy rose -

    Mr Speaker: In reply?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Yes, Sir. Sir, the Member for Telok Ayer says that he will not oppose this motion because I have said that these powers will be used sparingly and with the advice of the Trade Advisory Council. Sir, that is not correct. I have not said that these powers will be used with the advice of the Trade Advisory Council. The discretion lies solely with the Minister, Sir, and no Minister is going to give up that discretion if he has to exercise it for the benefit of the country.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to refer the hon. Member to section 4 (2) of the Ordinance which says:

Column: 307



    "Any order made by the Minister under this section shall as soon as possible after the making thereof be laid before the Legislative Assembly and if at the next meeting of the Legislative Assembly after the order is laid before it a resolution is passed annulling the order or any part thereof the whole order or such part thereof as the case may be shall thenceforth be void but without prejudice to the validity of anything previously done thereunder."

    If, Sir, any hon. Member dislikes any order made by the Minister, he has the right to move a motion annulling the order that the Minister has made at the next sitting of the Assembly when it is tabled. However, Sir, in normal matters we do consult the Trade Advisory Council, but it is not an assurance that I can give as a matter of right.

    The hon. Member also raised the point about Government demanding a guarantee that the rubber exported to China will not be used for war purposes. Sir, I am sure that hon. Members will agree that this Government can take a bit of credit for trying to get the ban on rubber exports to China removed. Sir, in keeping with the requirements of the United Nations Organisation, we have to get statements as to the end uses of the rubber that is being shipped to China. It is not a guarantee, in the real sense of a guarantee, from a shipper. It is a requirement that the shipper should give us the name of the ultimate user and the purpose for which the rubber is going there. He need not specifically state that it is going for tyre manufacture or something like that, so long as he states that it is going there for a purpose which is peaceful, and not connected with the production of war materials and so on. Sir, it is not a guarantee in the form that we hold the shipper responsible for the guarantee, but, of course, if it is found that the shipper has purposely made a false declaration, then there are penalties laid out in the Control of Imports and Exports Ordinance.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Assembly, in accordance with subsection (2) of section 1 of the Control of Imports and Exports Ordinance (Chapter 214), resolves that the aforesaid Ordinance

Column: 308

shall continue in force for a further period of one year commencing on the 8th day of December, 1956.

ARRESTS OF TRADE UNION AND CIVIC LEADERS AND DISSOLUTION OF SOCIETIES


    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion which stands in my name reads as follows:

    That this House is gravely concerned over the recent arrests of trade union and civic

Column: 316

leaders and the dissolution of two societies, and deplores the arbitrary manner of the Government's action.

    Since this motion was tabled, a number of developments have taken place which have made my motion out of date. There has been the dissolution of the Chinese Middle School Students Union and the arrest and detention under the Public Security Ordinance of the President of the Chinese Middle School Students Union and of an Executive Committee member of the People's Action Party, who is also an Assistant Secretary of the Shop and Factory Workers Union.
